channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Naismith Hall of Famer Grant Hill weighs in on NBA finals and Olympic goals ahead
item.description: Ahead of the NBA Finals tip-off, Grant Hill, Naismith Hall of Famer and minority owner of the Atlanta Hawks, talks about the identities of the Boston Celtics and Dallas Mavericks and who has the edge.
item.content:encoded: Ahead of the NBA Finals tip-off, Grant Hill, Naismith Hall of Famer and minority owner of the Atlanta Hawks, talks about the identities of the Boston Celtics and Dallas Mavericks and who has the edge.
item.dc:creator: Jason Fuller

item.title: Elon Musk’s giant Starship rocket rumbles into space once more
item.description: This is the fourth test for Starship, and this time, it returned successfully to earth.
item.content:encoded:
This is the fourth test for Starship, and this time, it returned successfully to earth.

(Image credit: Screenshot by NPR)
item.dc:creator: Geoff Brumfiel

item.title: Israel used a U.S.-made bomb in a deadly U.N. school strike in Gaza
item.description: Israel dropped a bomb on a U.N.-run school it said was being used by Hamas. The blast killed dozens, including women and children, medics and witnesses say. The bomb was U.S.-made, NPR has discovered.
item.content:encoded:
Israel dropped a bomb on a U.N.-run school it said was being used by Hamas. The blast killed dozens, including women and children, medics and witnesses say. The bomb was U.S.-made, NPR has discovered.

(Image credit: Anas Baba for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: They were there on D-Day, on the beaches and in the skies. This is what they saw
item.description: More than 150,000 U.S., British and Canadian troops stormed the beaches of Normandy, France, on June 6, 1944 — 80 years ago this week. A small handful told NPR about their experience.
item.content:encoded: More than 150,000 U.S., British and Canadian troops stormed the beaches of Normandy, France, on June 6, 1944 — 80 years ago this week. A small handful told NPR about their experience.
item.dc:creator: Jack Mitchell

item.title: A mother has been able to care for her son with SSI. But the program also limits them
item.description: The government program called Supplemental Security Income has lots of outdated rules that harm the people it's supposed to help, like people with significant disabilities and their caregivers.
item.content:encoded: The government program called Supplemental Security Income has lots of outdated rules that harm the people it's supposed to help, like people with significant disabilities and their caregivers.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Shapiro

item.title: Crows can count vocally like toddlers, research shows
item.description: Crows can count... out loud! They do so similarly to human toddlers who are learning to tally things up. A neuroscientist trained birds to produce a number of calls in response to random visual cues.
item.content:encoded: Crows can count... out loud! They do so similarly to human toddlers who are learning to tally things up. A neuroscientist trained birds to produce a number of calls in response to random visual cues.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Team USA beats Pakistan in Cricket World Cup
item.description: Team USA just pulled off one of the biggest upsets in cricket's history. They beat Pakistan in super-over in group play in this year’s World Cup.
item.content:encoded: Team USA just pulled off one of the biggest upsets in cricket's history. They beat Pakistan in super-over in group play in this year’s World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Ammad Omar

item.title: The Paris Olympics is already facing cybersecurity threats
item.description: From a fake Tom Cruise Netflix campaign to fear-mongering around terrorist attacks, the Paris Olympics already face online threats. Cybersecurity experts say those threats may only grow.
item.content:encoded: From a fake Tom Cruise Netflix campaign to fear-mongering around terrorist attacks, the Paris Olympics already face online threats. Cybersecurity experts say those threats may only grow.
item.dc:creator: Jenna McLaughlin

item.title: Anti-establishment candidate Nigel Farage could split the U.K.'s Conservative vote
item.description: An anti-establishment candidate has thrown a wrench into the U.K. election. Nigel Farage is running for Parliament with a new populist party -- which is likely to split the Conservative vote.
item.content:encoded: An anti-establishment candidate has thrown a wrench into the U.K. election. Nigel Farage is running for Parliament with a new populist party -- which is likely to split the Conservative vote.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: An auto plant in Alabama is offering employees up to $250 per month for child care
item.description: To attract workers, Mazda Toyota Manufacturing, a joint venture in northern Alabama, decided to offer a child care benefit. The company pays 30% of its employees child care costs, up to $250 a month.
item.content:encoded: To attract workers, Mazda Toyota Manufacturing, a joint venture in northern Alabama, decided to offer a child care benefit. The company pays 30% of its employees child care costs, up to $250 a month.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hsu
